For any topological additive group `G` and subset `s` of `G`, `s` is contained in the set `s ∪ {0} ⊔ cl {0}`, where `cl` denotes the topological closure and `⊔` denotes the set union with the closure.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddZeroClass G] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace G] (s : Set G), s ⊆ s + closure {0}
statement:
theorem subset_add_closure_zero :
    ∀ {G : Type w} [inst : TopologicalSpace G] [inst_1 : AddGroup G] (s : Set G), s ⊆ s + closure {0} := by sorry
name: subset_add_closure_zero
description: This theorem states that for any type `G` which is a topological space and an additive group, and for any set `s` of type `G`, `s` is a subset of the set obtained by adding `s` and the closure of the singleton set containing only the additive identity (0). In simpler terms, every element of `s` is also an element of the set formed by adding `s` and the closure of the set containing just 0.
concise-description: For any topological additive group `G` and subset `s` of `G`, `s` is contained in the set `s ∪ {0} ⊔ cl {0}`, where `cl` denotes the topological closure and `⊔` denotes the set union with the closure.

If `M` is an add monoid type and `x, y, z : M` with `y` and `z` being natural number multiples of `x`, then `y + z` is also a natural number multiple of `x`.

type: ∀ {M : Type u_1} [inst : AddMonoid M] {x y z : M}, y ∈ multiples x → z ∈ multiples x → y + z ∈ multiples x
statement:
theorem multiples.add_mem :
    ∀ {M : Type u_1} [inst : AddMonoid M] {x y z : M}, y ∈ multiples x → z ∈ multiples x → y + z ∈ multiples x := by
  sorry
name: multiples.add_mem
docString:
The set of natural number multiples of an element of an `AddMonoid` is closed under
addition.
description: The theorem states that for any type `M` that is an instance of an `AddMonoid`, and for any elements `y`, `z`, and `x` of that type, if `y` and `z` are in the set of natural number multiples of `x`, then the addition of `y` and `z` will also be in the set of natural number multiples of `x`. In other words, the set of natural number multiples of an element in an additive monoid is closed under addition.
concise-description: If `M` is an add monoid type and `x, y, z : M` with `y` and `z` being natural number multiples of `x`, then `y + z` is also a natural number multiple of `x`.

If `G` is a commutative additive monoid and `x` and `y` are elements of `G` with finite additive orders, then `x + y` also has finite additive order.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddCommMonoid G] {x y : G}, IsOfFinAddOrder x → IsOfFinAddOrder y → IsOfFinAddOrder (x + y)
statement:
theorem IsOfFinAddOrder.add :
    ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddCommMonoid G] {x y : G},
      IsOfFinAddOrder x → IsOfFinAddOrder y → IsOfFinAddOrder (x + y) :=
  by sorry
name: IsOfFinAddOrder.add
docString: Elements of finite additive order are closed under addition.
description: This theorem states that the property of having finite additive order is preserved under addition. More specifically, for any type `G` that forms a commutative additive monoid, if two elements `x` and `y` of `G` both have finite additive order, then their sum `x + y` will also have finite additive order. Here, an element having finite additive order means that there exists a non-zero integer `n` such that adding the element to itself `n` times results in the zero of the monoid.
concise-description: If `G` is a commutative additive monoid and `x` and `y` are elements of `G` with finite additive orders, then `x + y` also has finite additive order.
